article.body: This article is reprinted by permission from NerdWallet. This series examines the financial progress made by women in the U.S. since the Equal Credit Opportunity Act was passed in 1974. In this installment: the 1980s, the decade when Congress officially declared March as Womenâs History Month.Â Strides in continued education While college was largely a boysâ club in the early 20thÂ century, women turned that around during the 1980s. Beginning in the â80s, more than half of bachelorâs degrees were awarded to women, according to theÂ National Center for Education Statistics. Women also made up about half of graduates from masterâs programs and nearly 30% of graduates with doctorates for the 1980-1981 school year, though these degrees were disproportionately awarded to white women. As women became more educated, theirÂ salaries began to increase in relation to menâs salaries. The income gap wasnât closed during this time âÂ it remains today âÂ but it began shrinking as women attained more high-paying professional and managerial positions. The influenceÂ of the Equal Credit Opportunity Act of 1974Â âÂ which allowed women toÂ get a credit cardÂ separate from their husbandsÂ and ushered in a new level of financial freedomÂ âÂ continued to increase. Women now had more career options and more financial clout. Also on MarketWatch: What does retirement mean for women? Itâs important to note that the wage gap between women of different races existed in the â80s and still exists today. In 1989, white women working full time made a median weekly wage of $334, while Black women made $301 and Latina women made $269. According to the most recent data â from 2018 â while white womenâs median weekly wage was $817 and Asian women made $937, Black women had a median wage of $654 and Latina women made $617 a week. More from this series: In the 1970s, the Equal Credit Opportunity Act became lawâ a key step in financial freedom for women In the 1990s, women made strides in politics, and pop culture rewrites what it means to be a girl In the 2000s, the fight against pay discrimination continues In the 2010s, the Credit Card Act is amended and more women are breadwinners Advances in political power Women in the â80s madeÂ huge strides in politics. Sandra Day OâConnor became the first woman nominated to the Supreme Court in 1981.Â Geraldine Ferraro was the first female vice presidential candidate for a major party in 1984.Â EMILYâs ListÂ was founded in 1985 to help fund campaigns for Democratic women who supported abortion rights. Since it was started 35 years ago, EMILYâs List has helped nearly 1,300 women get elected to federal, state and local offices.Pop culture Television in the 1980s showcased women in the workplace supporting their families and themselves, while speaking out for womenâs rights and equality. TwoÂ TVÂ shows, âFamily Tiesâ and âThe Cosby Show,â werenât perfectly feminist sitcoms by any means, but they both starred strong, working female leads. Elyse Keaton on âFamily Tiesâ was a hippie-turned-work-at-home-mom who raised four children with her husband, Steven, over the course of the show. Both worked full time, Steven in an office, and Elyse at home as an architect. The show made it clear that a woman needs an identity outside of her family and the ability to bring in an income in order to thrive in the modern world. The matriarch of âThe Cosby Show,â Clair Huxtable â a working mother of five â delivers several pitch-perfect feminist speeches throughout the showâs eight seasons. She calls out the sexism of the men around her, refusing to bite her tongue when faced with chauvinistic attitudes. Clair was in a financial position that meant she arguably didnât need to work, but she chose to do so anyway.
